title: How to become a screenwriter - Ask a Screenwriter - Quora

response.answer_text: Read my book - The Complete Idiot's Guide to Screenwriting - Kindle edition by Skip Press. Humor & Entertainment Kindle eBooks @ Amazon.com.Read a lot of good screenplays, if possible while watching the movie, stop and start to see how the script is translated to screen - 50 Best Screenplays To Read And Download In Every GenreRead more scripts - Movie Scripts, Screenplays and TranscriptsIf you’re in L.A., go to events at the Academy (they’re cheap) and meet people - EventsWherever you live, try to meet pro writers - Meetup is a place to start - and see if you can get some good feedback.Learn what WGA signatory means and look up people to see if they are - Signatory Confirmation Lookups - that doesn’t mean they won’t try to screw you or steal from you - Hollywood does that a lot - but you need to learn who the more respectable producers might be. (I didn’t say, are.)Pay for a subscription to IMDbPro Start Your Free Trial because you can look people up and get in touch with them.All this time you should be writing a script. When it’s done, find a local theater company and either join it or see if you can wangle actors doing a staged reading of your work - you’ll learn more than you imagined about what’s good and what’s bad and whose opinions are only that.Register your script with the Library of Congress U.S. Copyright Office and don’t buy into the Hollywood lie that registering your script with the Writers Guild is the smartest way to protect yourself.When you sell a script, know that you’ll probably only be offered “scale plus 10 (percent, for the agent)” and that if you get more, you’re lucky. https://www.wga.org/uploadedfiles/contracts/2010_PBS_minimums.pdfFind a representative - currently there’s a crazy war with agens and the Writers Guild going on, but you can find a manager or entertainment attorney to rep you if someone wants to buy your work. A manager cannot legally negotiate for you per CA law but they do it, anyway. You’ll find as you go along that Hollywood largely doesn’t care about law, but cares quite a bit about money, and not money for you, money for them.You can always find me and ask a question and if I think it’s a good one I’ll answer it. Also, hang out here.
